segments.en: Linked Discourses 10
1. With Indaka
3. With Spiky

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gayāyaṃ viharati ṭaṅkitamañce sūcilomassa yakkhassa bhavane.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Gayā on the cut-stone ledge in the haunt of Spiky the native spirit.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kharo ca yakkho sūcilomo ca yakkho bhagavato avidūre atikkamanti.
segments.en: Now at that time the native spirits Shaggy and Spiky were passing by not far from the Buddha.

segments.pli: Atha kho kharo yakkho sūcilomaṃ yakkhaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: So Shaggy said to Spiky,
“That’s an ascetic.”
“That’s no ascetic, he’s a faker!

segments.pli: Yāva jānāmi yadi vā so samaṇo yadi vā pana so samaṇako”ti.
segments.en: I’ll soon find out whether he’s an ascetic or a faker.”

segments.pli: Atha kho sūcilomo yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato kāyaṃ upanāmesi.
segments.en: Then Spiky went up to the Buddha and leaned up against his body,
but the Buddha pulled away.

segments.pli: Atha kho sūcilomo yakkho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Spiky said to the Buddha,
“Are you afraid, ascetic?”
“No, sir, I’m not afraid.
But your touch is nasty.”
“I will ask you a question, ascetic.

segments.pli: Sace me na byākarissasi, cittaṃ vā te khipissāmi, hadayaṃ vā te phālessāmi, pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipissāmī”ti.
segments.en: If you don’t answer me, I’ll drive you insane, or explode your heart, or grab you by the feet and throw you to the far shore of the Ganges!”

segments.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ taṃ, āvuso, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya, yo me cittaṃ vā khipeyya hadayaṃ vā phāleyya pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipeyya;
segments.en: “I don’t see anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans who could do that to me.

segments.pli: api ca tvaṃ, āvuso, puccha yadā kaṅkhasī”ti. ()
segments.en: But anyway, ask what you wish.”
“Where do greed and hate come from?
From where do discontent, desire, and terror spring?
Where do the mind’s thoughts originate,
like a crow let loose by boys.”
“Greed and hate come from here;
from here spring discontent, desire, and terror;
here’s where the mind’s thoughts originate,
like a crow let loose by boys.
Born of affection, originating in oneself,
like the shoots from a banyan’s trunk;
the many kinds of attachment to sensual pleasures
are like camel’s foot creeper strung through the woods.
Those who understand where they come from
get rid of them—listen up, spirit!
They cross this flood so hard to cross,
not crossed before, so as to not be reborn.”

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Gayā…

suttaplex.blurb: The spirits Khara and Sūciloma argue about whether the Buddha is a true ascetic or not. They approach him initially with threats, but then ask as to the origin of greed and hate.
